Core:PCProperties.Core:Property:
(\{ (\{ "+\\
Merry Coding Standards for SkotOS\", "+\[unfinished document]\", "+", "+First of all, there \is\ no actual coding standard, in the \\"law sense\\". Nobody is required to follow the guidelines written here. Instead, these guidelines are written in order to allow people to make the choice whether they wish to write \\"compatible\\" code with the rest of the world. This standard is derived from that given to me by Nino a year or two ago, and is the standard I myself started using thencetoforth and am still using today. (And expect to be using for the rest of my life.)", "+", "+The various examples displayed are divided into five expressions -- optional, good, acceptable, bad, and unacceptable.", "+\\
`Optional´ means it isn't necessary, but is good practice nonetheless.\
\\
`Good' means it is the preferred method.\\
`Acceptable' means it is not recommended, but allowed.\\
`Bad' means you shouldn't do it, but would get away with it.\\
`Unacceptable´ means it is something you should not do, period, whether you are following this standard or not, and generally means your code is unreadable and unprofessional in style.\
\\\\
Indentation\Indentation is required, and should be four spaces long. Indentation should appear at:", "+\\
Every block-begin -- \\{\\\
f\\Good:", "+\
\if (x) \{\\
\\\r\\n\
EmitTo(\$actor, \\"Foo.\\");", "+\\r\\n\\\r\\n\
\\}\", "+\", "+Unacceptable:", "+\
\if (x) \{\", "+\\\
\EmitTo(\$actor, \\"Foo.\\");\\
\\\\\}\\
\\\r\\n\
Blocks\Blocks -- \{\} -- should be indented. The block-begin should appear at the same line as its initiating statement (e.g. for, if, switch, etc.).", "+", "+Good:", "+\
\for (x = 0; x \< 3; x++) \{\\
\
/* ... */", "+\\\}\", "+\", "+Bad:", "+\
\for (x = 0; x \< 3; x++) \\
\\{\\
\\r\\n\
/* ... */", "+\\r\\n\\\\r\\n\}\", "+\\r\\n\\\r\\n\\r\\n\
Unfinished non-blocked statements\If-, and for-statements sometimes contain single statements, and are sometimes left as is. This is bad unless doing so has obvious benefits to the appearance of the script, e.g. in the case of a series of if-cases in the form of a simplified switch logic.", "+", "+Good:", "+\
\if (x) \{\\
\\\r\\n\
EmitTo(\$actor, \\"X is.\\");", "+\\r\\n\\\r\\n\
\\}\", "+\", "+Acceptable:", "+\\r\\n\
\if (x) EmitTo(\$actor, \\"X is.\\");\
\\", "+Bad:", "+\
\if (x)", "+\\
\EmitTo(\$actor, \\"X is.\\");\\", "+\\\
Further on if cases", "+\If cases sometimes contain one or several else-statements which sometimes contain if cases of their own, which in turn may contain else-cases, and so on. While non-blocked if-cases are acceptable normally, in the case of if-cases with else statements, this is not so. The \\"else\\" keyword should be at the same line as the end-blocker and begin-blocker. In the case of an if case following an else-statement, the if case should be at the same line as the else-statement. Optionally, the initial if case's conditional parentheses may be aligned with the succeeding if cases'.", "+", "+Optional:", "+\
\if (x) \{\\
\\r\\n\\\r\\n\\r\\n\\r\\n\
EmitTo(\$actor, \\"X is.\\");", "+\\r\\n\\\r\\n\\r\\n\\r\\n\
\\} else if (y) \{", "+\\
\EmitTo(\$actor, \\"Y is.\\");", "+\\\\} else \{", "+\\\
\EmitTo(\$actor, \\"Neither X nor Y is.\\");", "+\\r\\n\\\\r\\n\
\\} \", "+\\\r\\n", "+Good:", "+\
\if (x) \{\\
\\r\\n\\\r\\n\\r\\n\
EmitTo(\$actor, \\"X is.\\");", "+\\r\\n\\\r\\n\\r\\n\
\\} else if (y) \{", "+\\
\EmitTo(\$actor, \\"Y is.\\");", "+\\r\\n\\\\r\\n\\}\\ else \{", "+\\r\\n\\\r\\n\\
\EmitTo(\$actor, \\"Neither X nor Y is.\\");", "+\\r\\n\\\\r\\n\\r\\n\
\\} \\\
\\r\\n\", "+Bad:", "+\
\if (x)\", "+\\\r\\n\\\\r\\n\
\EmitTo(\$actor, \\"X is.\\");", "+\\\
\\else if (y) ", "+\\
\EmitTo(\$actor, \\"Y is.\\");\\\\\
\\else\", "+\\\r\\n\\\\r\\n\
\EmitTo(\$actor, \\"Neither X nor Y is.\\");", "+\\\
", "+\\
\" \}), 1142270468, "zwoc" \})

"\
Merry Coding Standards for SkotOS\\\r\\n\\r\\n\\\r\\n\(unfinished document)\\\\r\\n\\\r\\nFirst of all, there \is\ no actual coding standard, in the \\"law sense\\". Nobody is required to follow the guidelines written here. Instead, these guidelines are written in order to allow people to make the choice whether they wish to write \\"compatible\\" code with the rest of the world. This standard is derived from that given to me by Nino a year or two ago, and is the standard I myself started using thencetoforth and am still using today. (And expect to be using for the rest of my life.)\\\r\\n\\\r\\nThe various examples displayed are divided into five expressions -- optional, good, acceptable, bad, and unacceptable.\\\r\\n\\
`Optional´ means it isn't necessary, but is good practice nonetheless.\\\r\\n\\\r\\n\
`Good' means it is the preferred method.\\\r\\n\
`Acceptable' means it is not recommended, but allowed.\\\r\\n\
`Bad' means you shouldn't do it, but would get away with it.\\\r\\n\
`Unacceptable´ means it is something you should not do, period, whether you are following this standard or not, and generally means your code is unreadable and unprofessional in style.\\\r\\n\\\r\\n\\\r\\n\\
Indentation\\\r\\n\\r\\nIndentation is required, and should be four spaces long. Indentation should appear at:\\\r\\n\\
Every block-begin -- \\\\\\{\\\\r\\n\
f\\\r\\n\\\r\\nGood:\\\r\\n\
\if (x) \\\\\{\\\\
EmitTo(\\\\\$actor, \\"Foo.\\");\\\r\\n\\
\\\\\\}\\\\r\\n\\\\r\\nUnacceptable:\\\r\\n\
\if (x) \\\\\{\\\\r\\n\\\
\EmitTo(\\\\\$actor, \\"Foo.\\");\\\\\\\\\\}\\\\r\\n\\\\
Blocks\\\r\\n\\r\\nBlocks -- \\\\\{\\\\\} -- should be indented. The block-begin should appear at the same line as its initiating statement (e.g. for, if, switch, etc.).\\\r\\n\\\r\\nGood:\\\r\\n\
\for (x = 0; x \\\\\< 3; x++) \\\\\{\\\
/* ... */\\\r\\n\\\\\\\}\\\\r\\n\\\\r\\nBad:\\\r\\n\
\for (x = 0; x \\\\\< 3; x++) \\\\\\\\{\\\
/* ... */\\\r\\n\\\\\\\}\\\\r\\n\\
Unfinished non-blocked statements\\\r\\n\\r\\nIf-, and for-statements sometimes contain single statements, and are sometimes left as is. This is bad unless doing so has obvious benefits to the appearance of the script, e.g. in the case of a series of if-cases in the form of a simplified switch logic.\\\r\\n\\\r\\nGood:\\\r\\n\
\if (x) \\\\\{\\\\
EmitTo(\\\\\$actor, \\"X is.\\");\\\r\\n\\
\\\\\\}\\\\r\\n\\\\r\\nAcceptable:\\\r\\n\
\if (x) EmitTo(\\\\\$actor, \\"X is.\\");\\\r\\n\\\\\r\\nBad:\\\r\\n\
\if (x)\\\r\\n\\
\EmitTo(\\\\\$actor, \\"X is.\\");\\\\\r\\n\\\\
Further on if cases\\\r\\n\\\r\\n\\r\\nIf cases sometimes contain one or several else-statements which sometimes contain if cases of their own, which in turn may contain else-cases, and so on. While non-blocked if-cases are acceptable normally, in the case of if-cases with else statements, this is not so. The \\"else\\" keyword should be at the same line as the end-blocker and begin-blocker. In the case of an if case following an else-statement, the if case should be at the same line as the else-statement. Optionally, the initial if case's conditional parentheses may be aligned with the succeeding if cases'.\\\r\\n\\\r\\nOptional:\\\r\\n\
\if (x) \\\\\{\\\\
EmitTo(\\\\\$actor, \\"X is.\\");\\\r\\n\\
\\\\\\} else if (y) \\\\\{\\\r\\n\\
\EmitTo(\\\\\$actor, \\"Y is.\\");\\\r\\n\\\\\\\\} else \\\\\{\\\r\\n\\\
\EmitTo(\\\\\$actor, \\"Neither X nor Y is.\\");\\\r\\n\\\
\\\\\\} \\\\r\\n\\\\r\\nGood:\\\r\\n\
\if (x) \\\\\{\\\\
EmitTo(\\\\\$actor, \\"X is.\\");\\\r\\n\\
\\\\\\} else if (y) \\\\\{\\\r\\n\\
\EmitTo(\\\\\$actor, \\"Y is.\\");\\\r\\n\\\\\\\\}\\ else \\\\\{\\\r\\n\\\
\EmitTo(\\\\\$actor, \\"Neither X nor Y is.\\");\\\r\\n\\\
\\\\\\} \\\
\\\\r\\nBad:\\\r\\n\
\if (x)\\\\r\\n\\\
\EmitTo(\\\\\$actor, \\"X is.\\");\\\r\\n\\\
\\else if (y) \\\r\\n\\
\EmitTo(\\\\\$actor, \\"Y is.\\");\\\\\\
\\else\\\\r\\n\\\\
\EmitTo(\\\\\$actor, \\"Neither X nor Y is.\\");\\\r\\n\\\
\
\\\r\\n\\\\r\\n\"
